case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the assessee

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1452 and 1502 of 1969 are cross-appeals by certificate from Calcutta High Court judgment dated September 13, 1968 in Income-tax Reference No. 101 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1452 1502 of 1969. Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 101 of 1966.

facts.text: Income-tax Tribunal B Bench, Calcutta stated a case and submitted five questions to High Court under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 at instance of assessee and Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee as well as the Commissioner, the Income-tax Tribunal B Bench, Calcutta stated a case and submitted as many as five questions to the High Court for obtaining its opinion.

facts.text: Assessee is a registered firm carrying on business mostly as managing agents of number of companies.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a registered firm which was carrying on business mostly as managing agents of number of companypanies.

facts.text: Till the end of February 1947, assessee firm consisted of four partners: A.C. Gladstone (30 shares), S.D. Gladstone (39 shares), T.S. Gladstone (30 shares), Glendye Limited (1 share) in profits.

anchor.surface_text: Till the end of February 1947, the firm companysisted of four partners namely  1  A.C. Gladstone  2  S. D. Gladstone  3  T. S. Gladstone and  4  Glendye Limited., each of them having, 30, 39, 30 and 1 shares respectively in the profits of the firm.

facts.text: Assessment year 1947-48 for assessee firm, previous year financial year ended March 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the assessment of the assessee firm for the assessment year 1947-48 for which the previous year was the financial year ended on March 31, 1947.

facts.text: On February 28, 1947, assessee firm through partners entered agreement for sale of shares and securities to Gillanders Arbuthnot & Co. (Company) for Rs. 75 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1947, the assessee firm through its partners entered into an agreement for sale of some of the shares and securities hold by it in favour of Gillanders Arbuthnot Co.  to be hereinafter referred to as the Company  for a sum of Rs. 75 lakhs.

facts.text: Clause 2 of agreement: existing partners admit Company as partner for Rs. 14.9 lakhs, Company gets 99% share in goodwill and profits.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  2  of that agreement provides In companysideration of the sum of Rupees Fourteen Lakhs and Ninety thousand the existing partners shall admit the companypany as a partner in the firm upon and subject to the partnership deed  a draft whereof has been already approved by the existing partners and the companypany , the share of the companypany in the goodwill and in the profits of the Finn being ninety-nine per cent thereof.

facts.text: Payment under clauses 1 and 2: Rs. 64.9 lakhs by allotment of 64,900 ordinary shares Rs.100 fully paid; Rs.25 lakhs by 25,000 redeemable cumulative preference shares Rs.100 fully paid.

anchor.surface_text: The said two sums of Rupees Seventy-five lakhs and Rupees Fourteen lakhs and Ninety thousand payable in accordance with Clauses 1 and 2 hereof shall be paid and satisfied as follows As to the sum of Rupees Sixty-four lakhs and Ninety thousand by an allotment to the existing partners or their numberinees of sixty-four thousand and nine hundred Ordinary Shares of rupees One hundred each credited for all purposes as fully paid up. As to the sum of Rupees Twenty-five lakhs by an allotment to the existing partners or their numberinees of Twenty-five thousand Redeemable Cumulative Preference Shares of Rupees One hundred each credited for all purposes as fully paid up.

facts.text: On February 28, 1947, assessee firm reconstituted with new partnership deed: five partners - Company (99%), A.C. Gladstone (0.25%), S. Gladstone (0.25%), T.S. Gladstone (0.25%), Glendye Limited (0.25%).

anchor.surface_text: One other document that came into existence on the same Jay viz. Feb. 28, 1947 is the deed of partnership. That day the assessee firm was reconstituted and a new partnership came into existence. The new partnership companysisted of five partners viz.  1  The companypany  2  A. C. Gladstone  3  S. Gladstone T. S. Gladstone and  5  Glendy Limited. In this new partnership the Company had 99 per cent share in its profits. The remaining four, partners had only 1/4th per cent share each in the profits of the new partnership.

facts.text: Company was previously a private limited company; in 1946 applied to Examiner of Capital Issues to convert to public ltd and sell shares at premium.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding further, it is necessary to mention that the Company, was previously a private Ltd. Company. In 1946 the Company applied to the Examiner of Capital Issues for permission to companyvert itself into a Public Ltd. Company and sell its shares at a premium.

facts.text: Original assessment of assessee for 1947-48 made on August 28, 1948 on total income Rs. 12,90,829.

anchor.surface_text: The, original assessment of the assessee firm for the assessment year 1947-48 was made on August 28, 1948 on a total income of Rs. 12,90,829/-

facts.text: Income-tax Officer initiated proceedings under s.34(1)(a) on May 2, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Income-tax Officer initiated proceedings under s. 34  1   a  on May 2, 1949 and companypleted the fresh assessment on January 16, 1956 bringing to charge capital gains determined at Rs. 1,03,16,786/-.

facts.text: Fresh assessment completed on January 16, 1956 with capital gains at Rs. 1,03,16,786.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Income-tax Officer initiated proceedings under s. 34  1   a  on May 2, 1949 and companypleted the fresh assessment on January 16, 1956 bringing to charge capital gains determined at Rs. 1,03,16,786/-

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner computed capital gains at Rs. 70,91,24 and rejected challenge to validity of s.34(1)(a) proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the companytention of the assessee that the proceedings under S. 34  1   a  were number validly initiated. He came to the companyclusion that there were capital gains but he companyputed the same at Rs. 70,9.124/-

facts.text: Tribunal held capital gains at Rs. 46,76,784.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal by the assessee the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the capital gains made by the assessee were only ,Rs. 46,76,784/-

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held capital gains at Rs. 27,04,772.

anchor.surface_text: In the Reference mentioned earlier, the High Court came to the Conclusion that the capital gains made by the assessee were Rs. 27,04,772/-

facts.text: Original cost of shares and securities to assessee as on January 1, 1939 was Rs. 47,95,728.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly their original companyt on January 1, 1939 was Rs. 47,95,728/Hence according to him, the Company secured those shares and securities at below market value.

facts.text: Sale deed executed by partners of assessee firm to Company on February 28, 1947 not placed before Income-tax Officer during original assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Though at the time of the original assessment of the assessee, the partnership deed entered into by the five partners was before the Income-tax Officer, the sale deed executed by the partners of the assessee firm in favour of the Company on February 28, 1947 had number been placed before him.

facts.text: Assessee submitted return in old form without Part VII for capital gains particulars.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the assessee submitted its return for the assessment year in question in an old form which did number companytain Pt. VII which dealt with particulars of income from capital gains.

facts.text: Supreme Court held proceedings under s.34(1)(a) validly initiated due to non-disclosure of material facts by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Tribunal and the High Court that there is hardly any doubt that the assessee had failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts for the purpose of ascertaining whether it had made any capital gains or number.

facts.text: Transaction of transfer of shares/securities was a sale for Rs.75 lakhs, not exchange or readjustment.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons above stated, we have numberhesitation in companying to the companyclusion that the transaction evidenced by the agreement for sale between the companypany and the assessee was a sale.

facts.text: Full value of consideration for sale is Rs.75 lakhs, capital gains Rs.27,04,772 as held by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles enunciated in that decision we think that the full value of the sale price received by the assessee was only rupees seventy five lakhs. That being so, the capital gains made by the companypany were Rs. 27,4 772/- as held by the High Court.

facts.text: Both appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: We agree with the Tribunal and the High Court that there is hardly any doubt that the assessee had failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts for the purpose of ascertaining whether it had made any capital gains or not.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Tribunal and the High Court that there is hardly any doubt that the assessee had failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts for the purpose of ascertaining whether it had made any capital gains or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee failed to disclose sale deed, particulars of shares/securities sale, used old return form without capital gains part; duty to disclose primary facts per Calcutta Discount Co.; ITO had prima facie grounds.

holdings.text: the words omission or failure to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year used in s. 34 postulate a duty on every assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment.

anchor.surface_text: the words omission or failure to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year used in s. 34 postulate a duty on every assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment. What facts are material and neces-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary facts must be disclosed by assessee; ITO draws inferences; follows Calcutta Discount Co., Hemchandra Kar, Bhanji Lavji, Burlop Dealers.

holdings.text: If there are in fact some reasonable grounds for the Income-tax Officer to believe that there had been any non-disclosure as regards the primary facts which could have a material bearing on the question of under-assessment that would be sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Income- tax Officer to issue the notice under s. 34.

anchor.surface_text: If there are in fact some reasonable grounds for the Income-tax Officer to believe that there had been any non-disclosure as regards the primary facts which could have a material bearing on the question of under-assessment that would be sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Income- tax Officer to issue the notice under s. 34. Whether those grounds were adequate or not for arriving at the ,conclusion that there was a non-disclosure of material facts is not open to the courts investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reason to believe is prima facie grounds; adequacy not for courts; follows precedents.

holdings.text: the first proviso to s. 12-B is not attracted to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for decision is whether the first proviso to s. 12-B is attracted to the facts of the present case. The sale with which we are concerned in this case took place on February 28, 1947. Section 12-B was incorporated into the Act with effect from April 1, 1947. That being so at the time the sale transaction took place s. 12-B was not a part of the Act. Hence there is no basis for saying that the transfer was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale on Feb 28, 1947 before s.12B effective Apr 1, 1947; no object of avoidance possible; follows George Henderson.

holdings.text: the transaction evidenced by the agreement for sale between the company and the assessee was a sale.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons above stated, we have no hesitation in coming to the conclusion that the transaction evidenced by the agreement for sale between the company and the assessee was a sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement explicitly sale for Rs.75 lakhs; payment by shares satisfaction of price, not exchange; follows Ramakrishna Pillai distinguishing sale from exchange.

holdings.text: the legal effect of a transaction cannot be displaced by probing into the substance of the transaction.

anchor.surface_text: But the legal effect of a transaction cannot be displaced by probing into the substance of the transaction. This, principle applies alike to cases in which the legal relation is recorded in a formal document and to cases where it has to be gathered, from evidence-oral and documentary-and conduct of the parties to the transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits substance over form; true legal relation determines taxability; disapproves prior cases like Sir Kikabhai, Homi Mehta; follows B.M. Kharwar.

holdings.text: the full value of the sale price received by the assessee was only rupees seventy five lakhs. That being so, the capital gains made by the company were Rs. 27,04,772/- as held by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles enunciated in that decision we think that the full value of the sale price received by the assessee was only rupees seventy five lakhs. That being so, the capital gains made by the company were Rs. 27,04,772/- as held by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full value is bargained price Rs.75 lakhs in sale; not market value; proviso not attracted; follows George Henderson; distinguishes from fair market value in proviso.

holdings.text: In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court on validity of proceedings, applicability of s.12B, quantum of gains.

anchor.surface_text: If there are in fact some reasonable grounds for the Income-tax Officer to believe that there had been any non-disclosure as regards the primary facts which could have a material bearing on the question of under-assessment that would be sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Income- tax Officer to issue the notice under s. 34. Whether those grounds were adequate or not for arriving at the ,conclusion that there was a non-disclosure of material facts is not open to the courts investigation.
In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for decision is whether the first proviso to s. 12-B is attracted to the facts of the present case. The sale with which we are concerned in this case took place on February 28, 1947. Section 12-B was incorporated into the Act with effect from April 1, 1947. That being so at the time the sale transaction took place s. 12-B was not a part of the Act. Hence there is no basis for saying that the transfer was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee
In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.
For the reasons above stated, we have no hesitation in coming to the conclusion that the transaction evidenced by the agreement for sale between the company and the assessee was a sale.

In the result both these appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.
